abstract.p: Embroidered quilts of late 19th century are focus of Deborah Harding's book Red and White: American Redwork Quilts; photo (S)

block.p: American women have long applied fine needlepoint to pillows, tapestries and patchwork quilts. But a new trend arose at the 1876 Centennial in Philadelphia: the embroidery of everyday items like doilies, dresser scarves and dish towels. Patterns showing birds, flowers and the like were usually from magazines like Harper's Bazar (as it was then spelled), said Deborah Harding, the author of ''Red and White: American Redwork Quilts'' (Rizzoli, $39.95). The designs also found their way onto quilts, above, and were embroidered in red because the most colorfast thread of the time was red: Turkey red.
